newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Dutch aim for swift EU entry of eastern Europe.
newsitem.headline: Dutch aim for swift EU entry of eastern Europe.

text.p: The Dutch government said on Wednesday it would use its forthcoming presidency of the European Union to try to wrap up talks on a new EU treaty as quickly as possible to allow enlargement into eastern Europe.
Dutch prime minister Wim Kok said membership talks for countries such as Poland should start early in 1998.

"The best possible contribution (during the presidency) we can make is to bring the IGC to a quick close," Kok told a news conference after official talks with his Polish counterpart Wlodzimierz Cimoszewicz.
The Dutch six-month presidency of the EU begins in January and includes the Inter-Governmental Conference (IGC), due to be finalised by mid-June.
Eastern European countries, including Poland, have been told the EU would like them to begin membership negotiations six months after the close of the meeting.
Kok said preparations by applicant nations would be key to a swift conclusion.
"It would be deplorable if the process of preparation took too long. The sooner, the better," he said.
Kok said the talks had also touched on the enlargement of NATO, which Poland is keen to join, and he expects a decision on new members to be taken next year.
Kok said he could easily see Poland as a NATO member at some point but stressed the key issue facing the organisation was to reach an agreement with Russia.
"Either as an enlarged or non-enlarged NATO, we need an agreement with Russia. It is childish to think you can have peace and stability in Europe without it," he said.
